thread.title: Xiaomi officially enters Pakistan, will give warranty for its phones : News, News - India Today
thread.title_full: Xiaomi officially enters Pakistan, will give warranty for its phones : News, News - India Today

author: Priya Pathak
title: Xiaomi officially enters Pakistan, will give warranty for its phones : News, News - India Today
text:
Last Updated: FEB 22, 2017 New Delhi Email Author 
After months of speculations, China's 'Apple' Xioami has now officially forayed into Pakistan. The company has partnered with Smart Link Technologies and Rocket Internet's ecommerce marketplace, Daraz for the distribution and after sales services. 
According to a Masbhable report, Xiaomi will kickstart its operations in the country with the launch of hit budget smartphones like Redmi Note 4, Note 4 A and Mi-Max. In fact, some of Mi devices are already listed on the Daraz website. The company says that all the Xiaomi products arriving to Pakistan will come with guaranteed warranty and full after sales service. 
Pakistan is the world's sixth most populous country and as per a PTO report, adds over one million people coming online every year through smartphones. According to an IDC report, the country last year saw 13 million smartphone shipments. Apart from leading Chinese smartphone brands like Oppo and Huawei which have been around for several years, many domestic smartphone makers like QMobile and Infinix are also amongst the best sellers in Pakistan. Also Read: Xiaomi to launch its Pinecone chipset on February 28 
According to a Dawn report, Pakistan Telecom Authority(PTA), last year had barred Xiaomi from selling smartphones in the country. A PTA official while talking to the newspaper said that the company did not get the approval from the authority as the it failed to abide by the bye rules and laws of the country. However, the official could not confirm of any type-approval applied by the company then.Xiaomi in 2014 first announced its expansion outside China. The company first entered the Singapore market and later reached to Malaysia, Philippines, India and Brazil.
